text: From overhead, we see a Toyota Prius chugging along down highway.

When you’re the president of the 98th largest financial services company in America you need to project a certain image. An image of boldness, strength and confidence. Suddenly, a brand new, shiny black Porsche Boxster convertible ZOOMS around the Prius, leaving it in the dus As we move in, we see the driver of the Porsche is NICK HENDRICKS. Sunglasses. Top down. Wind in his hair. He looks pretty cool.
You’re not gonna get that image driving a Prius.

Nick pulls into the lot and takes a reserved spot near th entrance with a sign that reads “NICK HENDRICKS, PRESIDEN He gets out of the Porsche and removes the dealer’s paper floormat from under the pedals.

I put in a lot of years to become president of Comnindyne and now I’m earning a lot more and working a lot... more. The strange thing is, when I finally made it to the top, I realized that I’d actually only made it to the bottom of the top. Nick heads toward the building, passing several parking s with much more expensive sports cars (Ferrari, Porsche 91 Turbo, Mercedes SLR McLaren) each with a sign bearing a n and the title “PRESIDENT.”
Turns out Comnidyne has seven presidents. And I’m the most junior.
Nick enters to find his more senior COLLEAGUES in their morning meeting.

Hey, sorry I’m late. (holding up keys) Had to stop by the dealership to pick up a little something. The others all react, impressed. PETER, 40's, squat, gnom like, heads to the window which looks down at the parking lot.
Well done. Hendricks got himself some big boy wheels. Another colleague, ARTHUR, 60’s, joins them at the window
(looking outside) Which one is she?
(pointing) Right there. She’s the Porsche.
Barely. You got a Boxster?
Uh huh. Two-thousand thirteen. A sallow-looking woman, JEANINE, 50's, chimes in.
Cost you that much? The others all laugh derisively.
It’s a great little car.
That’s adorable. You’re a great little man. GLEN, 50's, hairpiece and jowls, steps up.
I got my daughter a Boxster for her Sweet 16. Made me take it back. Said it was “too girly.” They all laugh again. Nick grits his teeth.
Okay. Maybe we should get to work.
You couldn't at least spring for the Carrera?
Figured I’d go with the classic.
Uh, the Boxster was introduced about forty years after the Carrera. So, not exactly “a classic.”
(patting him on the shoulder) Don’t worry, Nick. Another ten years here, you'll be able to afford a real car. Nick stares at her.

All right, guys. Looks like the Swiss are about to change their drawdown regs, so we need to talk about a new home for our master feeder fund. The presidents turn back to the piles of paperwork on the table in front of them and resume their dreary work. As t talk, the sound drops down and we PUSH IN on Nick as he stares at his colleagues.

You know what’s at the top of the corporate ladder? Another goddamn ladder. I may be a president, but I'm really just a fucking corporate tool. FREEZE ON Nick’s forlorn expression as the words appear o him:
We find KURT BUCKMAN sitting poolside on a chaise lounge, reading US Weekly and sipping a can of beer.

You're probably wondering, “how does this handsome bastard get to sit by the pool with a beer on a workday?” Well, here’s how: you quit your job, find a sugar mama whose rich husband is out of the picture and let her take care of you. He puts the magazine over his face and is about to take a nap.
Kurt! Refill! Kurt sets the magazine aside and springs to his feet.
Kurt enters, carrying three glasses of mojitos. Sitting o the couch is RHONDA HARKEN and her friends, NIKKI, late 3 a lot of work done, and HEIDI, early 40’s, even more work
Does it bother me that my sugar mama happens to be the ex-wife of the man who tried to kill me and my friends? Meh.
(to the girls) She spends thousands on Botox. She should spend 50 cents on a razor for that moustache.
She looks like Tom Selleck with fake boobs! The girls cackle. Kurt quietly sets the glasses on the coffee table and turns to go.
Kurt. Really?
What?
The table. It’s African bubinga wood. I’ve told you. Use a coaster.
Right. Sorry.  He puts a coaster under each glass.
Thank you. (back to the girls) Speaking of Erica, have you seen how fat her husband has gotten?
Have you seen my tub of shit lately? He’s gained thirty pounds since the holidays.
(to Rhonda, indicating Kurt) At least you got a good one. Kurt grins, flattered.
He’s okay. Kurt’s smile fades.
Getting a little doughy in the middle.
I don’t believe it.
It’s true. (to Kurt) Pop that shirt off. Show them.
Huh?
The shirt. Pop it off.
I’m not gonna--
(sternly) Pop it.
Rhonda, I really don’t--
Pop. It. Off.  Resigned, Kurt takes his shirt off. He’s in pretty good shape.
Look at that.
He looks all right to me.
No, look. She grabs what belly fat Kurt has, pinching and jiggling
Hey.
How do we get rid of this? Because this is gross. Here, touch it. As the other women begin to poke and prod Kurt’s abdomen, sighs heavily.

I guess the only real downside of this whole arrangement is that sometimes I feel kinda, I don’t know, bad about myself. Like I've turned into a ball-less little bitch. FREEZE ON Kurt as the words appear over him:

EXT. DALE’S HOUSE - DAY DALE ARBUS opens the front door of his tiny house. His VE pregnant wife, STACY, bids him goodbye. Dale leans in to kiss her, but her enormous belly makes it hard to reach h face.

It’s all happening. I got married. Stacy’s pregnant-- with triplets! And I finally got my sex offender status expunged. Which is great, because otherwise I’d have to stay 100 yards from my own kids. Dale crosses to his car and pulls out of the driveway.  EXT. DR. SLOCUM’S OFFICE - SHORT TIME LATER Dale pulls into the parking lot, passing a sign that read “DR. HARLEN SLOCUM, PEDIATRIC DENTIST” above an image of cartoon TOOTH having its own tooth pulled by another TOOT dressed as a dentist.

I quit my dental assistant job and got a new job. As a dental assistant. But for a really sweet man. INT. DR. SLOCUM’S OFFICE HALLWAY - MOMENTS LATER Dale walks down a hallway, passing framed photos of DR. SLOCUM in his dental scrubs at age 35... 45... 55... 75.. 80-something.
A really sweet, really, really old man.

Dale enters a world of CHAOS populated by screaming KIDS a handful of exhausted PARENTS. Toys lie strewn everywher A group of TODDLERS tear the upholstery out of a sofa cushion. A RECEPTIONIST sits at a desk, oblivious. Dale takes a step and TRIPS over something off-camera. He looks down and picks up the CRYING INFANT he stumbled on.
Okay, whose baby is this? You can’t just leave your babies on the floor. A harried MOTHER takes the baby from him as he carefully picks his way across the kid-covered floor.
Dale enters to find a 4 YEAR-OLD BOY, GABE, hollering miserably as DR. SLOCUM, 80’s, sits slumped asleep with dental tools still inside Gabe’s open mouth.
Not again. Dale hurries over and nudges the dentist awake.
Dr. Slocum! Wake up. You're with a patient.
(groggy) What?! I know. What?! Dale gently removes the tools from Gabe’s mouth. Gabe sto yelling.
(to Gabe) You're okay, buddy. (checking) Nothing bleeding here.
I have to pee.
Okay. Bathroom’s down the hall.
Someone has to take me.
Where’s your mommy?
She’s at Target.
Oh. Okay, I’ll take you.
Hang on. I’ve got to check his lower left cuspid.
He’s gotta go to the bathroom, doctor.
Fine. Dale escorts the boy out.
Dale leads Gabe to the bathroom door.
Okay. Here you go.
You have to come in and help me.
Help you? What do you mean?
You have to unbutton my pants.
I don’t think that’s a great idea, Gabe.
Please! I have to go! Dale looks around furtively.
Okay, come on. (hustling him inside) Quick, quick, come on. INT. BATHROOM —- CONTINUOUS Dale and Gabe enter. Dale locks the door behind them and starts uncomfortably undoing Gabe’s pants.

(mumbling) It’s just that I recently had something expunged from my record. It was a big misunderstanding. Empty playground. No kids anywhere. But I really shouldn’t be doing this... He gets the pants open and heads for the door.
Okay. You’re good to go. I’1l wait outside.
No! You have to aim for me.
What?! No one’s taught you how to aim? Gabe shakes his head.
What kind of parenting-- Is your mom always at Target?  10.
I’m gonna go in my pants!
I’m gonna go to jail! Gabe does a desperate pee pee dance.
Please! It hurts!

Aw man. You’re really gonna make me do this? (sighs) All right. Let’s get it over with. Dale takes a latex glove from his dental scrubs and pulls on his hand. With his arm outstretched and looking the ot way, he helps Gabe aim (off-screen). We hear the sound of peeing.
There you go. (to himself) This is not a good situation.
A mortified Dale leads Gabe back to the exam room. Dale peels off his glove and tosses it in a bin.
Feel better?
Yes. Thank you.

You’re welcome. (beat) Now, you don’t necessarily have to tell your mom that I helped you pee. It can be our secret. (quickly) Not a secret. Just a fun thing that we never tell anyone else. (quickly) Not a fun thing. Just a secret. INT. DR. SLOCUM’S OFFICE - SHORT TIME LATER Dale peers through the blinds and sees Gabe getting in a with his MOTHER.  11. The car pulls out of its parking spot and drives forward fifty feet or so, then SCREECHES to a halt, SLAMS into reverse and ZOOMS back into the parking lot. Dale looks like he’s going to puke as Gabe’s mother exits car and marches toward the building.
Oh shit oh shit oh shit... He hurries to the waiting room to head her off.
Dale bursts through the door to find Gabe’s mother walkin to the receptionist.
Let me expl-- GABE’S MOTHER (to Receptionist) I completely forgot to schedule Gabe’s next appointment. Dale lets out an enormous sigh of relief.
I guess if I’m being honest, this job stresses the crap out of me. I’m not so much a dental assistant as a goddamn babysitter. We FREEZE on Dale’s face as the words appear:
Nick, Kurt and Dale sit at a table with drinks. Like Nick most of the PATRONS wear business attire. Many are older. PIANIST plays soft jazz in one corner.
(to Dale) What’s the deal with you and little kids’ dicks?
There weren't “dicks.” It was just one. You make it sound like it was a boys choir!  12.
I don’t know, Dale. I’m starting to see a pattern here. I mean, if I had been on the sex offender registry, I'd try and avoid handling kids’ private parts.
(to Dale) I don’t think I can be friends with you anymore.
Yeah, feels like two strikes is enough.
What was I supposed to do? Let the kid piss in his pants?
Yeah./Uh huh.
You guys don’t get it. You’re not fathers-to-be. You don’t have the instinct to protect children.
I have the instinct to protect them from people like you.
Very funny.
How’s Stacy feeling?
Pregnant. Very pregnant. I don’t think the human body is designed to carry three babies.
Are you grossed out by her body?
No! Of course not. It’s beautiful. (off their looks) It’s a little gross. She’s got this weird line that runs down her belly.
Yeesh. Not worth it, I say.  13. A WAITER sets down a fresh dish of olives, removing the o dish full of pits. Dale eagerly begins eating the new one
Dale, that’s your fourth bowl of olives.
I like olives.
Just because they keep bringing them doesn’t mean you have to keep wolfing them down.
But I like ‘em.
(to Nick) What do you care?
It’s embarrassing. This is a classy place.
It’s a bullshit place. I don’t know why you drag us here all the time.
Yeah, what was wrong with our old bar?
This is much nicer.
Hotel bars suck. The beer costs ten bucks and the women are either old or hookers I can’t afford.
And that bathroom attendant expects me to pay him for paper towels, so I can’t even wash my hands. Kurt and Nick grimace as Dale roots through the olive dis
(to Nick) I know why you like this place. You’re a fancypants.
What?  14.
Admit it. Since you became president, you’ve gotten all fancy.
I’m not a fancypants.
Dale?
(to Nick) You're a little fancy.
Fuck you guys.
Hey, hey. That’s not a very fancy thing to say. (then) It’s just that lately you seem to care a lot more about where you drink, what you wear, what kind of car you drive--
How many olives I eat.
Look, when you get to my position, people expect certain things of you.
But you’re the boss. Doesn’t that Mean you don’t have to care what people think of you anymore?
It’s more complicated than that.
Hey, as long as it’s making you happy.

Yeah. We stay on NICK. It’s pretty clear that he is not happy. From the hallway outside the bar, they suddenly hear MUSI blaring over a loudspeaker. It’s “I GOTTA FEELING” by The Black Eyed Peas, accompanied by CHEERING from what sounds like a decent-sized crowd.  15.
What’s going on out there? They exchange a curious look.

Nick, Kurt and Dale open the door find a motivational sem in progress. An audience of around 100 PEOPLE sit in rows seats as the music BOOMS from a PA. On a riser at the fro of the room, an energetic 40-something man claps along to song.
Who is that?
You don’t know who that is? That’s Denny Paul.
How do you know him?
From his sign. Dale points behind them to a sign featuring a headshot of DENNY PAUL beneath the title “YOU DA BOSS!” Denny picks up a mic as the music fades out.
Am I the only one who has a feeling that tonight is gonna be a good, good night?!
Let's go. Nick and Kurt start to go.
Wait. Let’s see what Denny has to say.
Show of hands. Who here had a vision when they were younger of where they wanted their life to go? Most of the crowd raises their hands.
Okay. Now how many of you are living that vision? Who here is living their “vision life”?  16. Only a few hands go up. Denny “scans” the crowd.
Hmm. I don’t see any hands. Oh wait, here’s one. Boom. He puts up his own hand and points at it. Nope.
That’s right. This guy with his hand up? You know who he is? He’s me. Just little old me. Living my vision life. Wanna know how I did it?
Don’t care.

I grabbed the reins of the horse that was my life and I slapped that horse's ass and I made it ride where I wanted it to ride. Not down some shitty path that the horse wanted to ride. Because horses are idiots.
He’s not wrong.

Here’s the deal, gang: the only people who are truly happy in this crazy world are the ones who don’t have to answer to anybody. They’re their own boss. They control their destiny. ANGLE ON Nick and Kurt who are actually listening now.

See, I used to be just like you. A drone. No self-respect. Working for the man. Then I realized, I am the man. I quit my job, left my loveless marriage and started my own business... helping other people start their own business. And here’s the kicker, folks. Last year, I made in the very high five figures. Guess what? Vision life. Lovin’ it. Denny drops the mic to the floor. The crowd applauds appreciatively. After a moment, Denny picks up the mic again.  17.
So let’s get into the fifteen steps. Step one: take a good look at yourself in the mirror, or any reflective surface: a shiny pan, a still puddle-- A HOTEL EMPLOYEE approaches the guys.
Excuse me, gentlemen, can I see your tickets, please? Nick, Kurt and Dale all shake their heads and wander out the ballroom.
The guys are back in the bar.
All I’m saying is, Denny Paul has a point. I thought that when I went to work for Dr. Slocum I’d be happier. But my job still kinda sucks.
I hear you, Dale. I’m not exactly living the dream either.
Seriously? Have you learned nothing? You want to kill your bosses again?
What? No! I just mean, maybe the problem wasn’t working for our old bosses. Maybe the problem is working for anyone.
I don’t work for anyone.
You kinda do.
(to Kurt) Mrs. Harken treats you like a slave.
You don’t have sex with a slave.  18.
Thomas Jefferson did.
(noticing) Hey, look. ANGLE ON Denny Paul drinking a whisky at the bar.

It’s Denny Paul. (calling to him) Denny! Mr. Paul! (Denny looks over) Can we buy you a drink? Nick and Kurt grimace. Denny shrugs, downs his drink, signals the bartender for another one, and ambles over to them. He looks fairly drunk.
What are you doing?
Buying him a drink.
Doesn't really look like he needs one.
(a bit slurred) What’s up, guys?
We really enjoyed your seminar--
We snuck in.
And we left after five minutes.
Candor alert! Look out. The Waiter sets down Denny’s drink. He downs it in one gu and gestures for another.
(sotto to Nick) Alcoholic alert.
Look out.  19.
I’m Dale. This is Nick and Kurt. We were just talking about how great it would be to be our own bosses.
If talking was doing, a telephone would be a hammer.
Not sure I get that.
That’s only because it makes no sense.
How did you do it, Denny? Did you follow your own fifteen steps? Denny looks at them and considers for a beat.
Buy me another drink. Dale signals the waiter.
(leaning in) You wanna know a secret? The fifteen steps are bullshit.
No!
Get out of town.
Yeah. I just made ‘em up. People love steps. And they love being told what to do.
So, what do we do? Tell us?
You want to know how I started my business? He fumbles for his wallet, taking it out and handing them business card.
(reading) International Venture Partners?  20.
Bingo. Venture capital. These guys set me up with enough cash to get “You Da Boss” off the ground.
What’s the catch?
No catch. They take a 10 percent ownership stake. They make money when you make money. You just gotta have a good enough idea.
And “You Da Boss” was a good enough idea?
Did you see that crowd tonight? I’m a very charismatic guy. Denny notices a WOMAN in a pencil skirt walk past.
Excuse me. Are you a prostitute? The guys look horrified.
(after a beat) Yes.
(getting up) All right, guys. Good luck with... whatever we were talking about. He stumbles off with the prostitute. Kurt and Nick watch go, incredulous. Dale stares at the business card.
Hmm. A lot to think about. INT. HARKEN’S HOUSE - LATER Nick, Kurt and Dale enter from the front door.
Keep your voices down. I don’t want to wake her.
It’s past your curfew, isn’t it?  They head Relieved, 21.
You want to get smacked?
(quietly) No. into the living room.
(looking around nervously) Does she still have that cat?
No. He ran away months ago.
Good. Nick sits on the sofa. As he does, a CAT leaps onto his shoulder from behind with a YOWL and darts away.
What the hell?! You said he ran away.
That’s the new cat.
What, does she rescue them from a haunted house? Kurt pours drinks from a wet bar and they all sit. Dale s his drink on the table.
Dale! Use a coaster. That’s bubinga wood.
(to Kurt) Who are you?
(holding up business card) I think we should seriously consider this venture capital thing.
They don’t just hand you money, Dale. You need to pitch them a good business idea.
Like an invention?  22.
Could be.
I’ve got a ton of ideas for inventions.
(dubious) Do you?
You know how your dick sticks to your balls when it’s hot out?
Um...
Picture this: underwear with compartments that separate your dick from your balls.
No one’s gonna fund that.
When it’s hot out, they will. We'll just pitch it on a hot day.
That's a stupid idea. (beat) It should be a non-stick spray for your balls, like Pam.
Much better.
Wait, wait, I got one. Regular sized condoms that are packaged in Magnum condom wrappers. So the girl you're with thinks you’ve got a big dick.
Ooh, that just gave me an idea. A condom in a spray can. It goes on as a liquid, and then it hardens into a solid.
You're just taking my ideas and putting them in spray cans. (then) (MORE )
And how are you supposed to remove the rubber after it’s fused onto your penis?
It’ll come with an antidote spray. Some kind of acid. That’s for our lab guys to figure out.
(to Dale and Kurt) Why do all of your inventions have to do with dicks and balls?
I don’t know. Why were all of the Wright Brothers’ ideas about planes?
Maybe Nick’s right. Maybe we need to focus more on vagina inventions.
No, the key to a good invention is that it solves some everyday problem. They sit there and think for a minute.
Okay, here’s an everyday problem: showering. You gotta shampoo, condition, lather up, rinse, repeat. It takes forever. There’s a beat.
So what’s the invention?
I don’t know. I thought we were just talking about problems.
I think I’m gonna go to bed.
One sec. Dummy may be onto something. It does seem like showering is pretty inefficient.
Right? I bet the average person loses a day every week just showering.  24.
(re: Dale’s math) Feels wrong.
What if there was some kind of a showerhead that you fill with soap, shampoo and conditioner and it mixes it with the water?
Yeah! You could turn a dial to choose what you want it to spray. Like those Miracle-Gro things you attach to a garden hose.
Right. They turn to Nick for his reaction.
It’s... not terrible. But I’m sure it already exists.
The guys stand around a laptop computer. On the screen is Google search for “showerhead with built-in soap.”
Not finding it.
Try Bed, Bath & Beyond. They’ve got everything. Kurt does.
Nope.
So, should we call that venture capital guy?
It’s 2 in the morning, Dale. And you don’t have a prototype or even a name for this thing.
How about... the Shower Buddy?  25.
That sounds like a gay friend who soaps up your back in the shower.
I don’t know why you go right to “gay.” (types on laptop) Let’s see what comes up under “Shower Buddy.” They all cringe and recoil at what appears on screen.
Okay, that’s pretty gay. But it’s not a product.
It’s more of a... position. Rhonda enters in a bathrobe.
What’s going on in here? Kurt hastily slams the laptop shut on Dale’s hand. She shuts
Ow!
Just hanging out with the guys, hon.
Do you know what time it is? Some of us have to work in the morning.
(under his breath) You don’t work.
I’ve got yoga at ten. And I don’t appreciate the attitude. It’s time to say goodnight to your friends.
But-- him down with a look.
(to Nick and Kurt) You guys better go.  26.
What about our Shower Buddy? Rhonda looks confused. Kurt herds Nick and Dale toward th door.
Forget it, Dale. It’s silly.
I don’t think it’s silly. I think it could be the key to our vision life.
Goodnight, Kurt. Rhonda. Nick and Dale exit. Rhonda heads for the stairs.
Let’s go. Upstairs. My pussy’s not going to eat itself. Kurt sighs, then slumps out after her. MUSIC CUE: “Modern Man” by Arcade Fire

Nick walks to his Boxster and stops abruptly when he sees BUMPER STICKER has been stuck to his rear bumper that rea “My Other Car is a Porsche” Nick tries to peel it off, but only part of the top layer comes off. Pissed, he looks around and notices his fellow PRESIDENTS watching from a window and laughing their asse off at him.

Kurt stands at the checkout counter as a CUTE FEMALE CASH rings up his purchases. He gives her a flirty smile which she returns... until she sees what he’s buying: Secret deodorant, Oil of Olay, and an enormous value pack of tampons. He hands her a credit card. INSERT the card: it belong to Rhonda Harken and has her photo on it. The cashier looks at him dubiously. Kurt shrugs sheepishl  27. INT. DR. SLOCUM’S EXAM ROOM - DAY Dale sits on his stool making detailed, yet crudely drawn sketches on a steno pad of the proposed “Shower Buddy” device. He smiles, pleased, then looks up to see Dr. Sloc has fallen asleep and the dental chair is empty. He looks around frantically and gasps when he spots the PATIENT, a five year-old girl, who has climbed halfway ou the window. Dale hurries over to rescue her.

Dale’s car pulls up to a sleek, modern building. INT. DALE'S CAR —- CONTINUOUS Dale wears a slightly tattered business suit. He takes ou of his pocket the International Venture Partners card tha Denny Paul gave them and double checks the address. INT. MR. NAGOPIAN’S OFFICE - LATER Dale sits on a couch in a well-appointed office and finis his pitch to someone offscreen. Beside him stands an ease with his Shower Buddy sketch tacked to it.

The Shower Buddy eliminates the endless cycle of washing and rinsing and washing and rinsing. It’s not just a time saver. It’s a life saver. My team is ready to move on this with or without your help. But the only way we can do that is with your help. REVERSE ON ALEX NAGOPIAN, 40's, well dressed, confident a slightly intimidating (think Liam Neeson). Beside him sit JOYCE, 30's, an attractive colleague. Nagopian considers Dale's pitch for a beat.
You're a funny little man, Dale.
Go on.
As far as your idea, this “Shower Buddy”? (beat) I love it.  28.
Seriously?!
Yes. It’s smart, it fills a niche. What do you think, Joyce?
Sounds like the kind of product we like to fund.
Of course, our due diligence people will have to make sure no one else has done it.
Well, we googled it and didn’t find anything.
I see. And why aren’t your partners here with you?
They’re very busy men. We all are. Very busy. Men.
But you have power of attorney to sign on their behalf? Dale stares at him for a beat.
...yes. (then) Does this mean we’re in business?
That depends. How much do you need to get the Shower Buddy off the ground?
Do you have a piece of paper?
Why?
So I can write down the amount and slide it across the table to you. Nagopian looks mildly annoyed. He nods to Joyce, who tear piece of paper off a pad and hands it to Dale.  29.
Great. Thanks. I’ve always wanted to do this. Dale scribbles on the paper and slides it across the coff table. Nagopian looks at it.
I can’t read this. Is this a “2"?
(leaning in) Looks like a “G.”
No, that’s a “9.”
Then I don’t understand this number. You have two commas next to each other.
No, no, that’s not a comma. That’s also a nine-- you know what? Let me write it again--
Why don’t you just say the number?
(tentatively) Nine hundred ninety-nine thousand, nine-hundred, ninety nine dollars?
Why not an even million?
It sounds like less?
This isn’t the Radio Shack. A million is fine.
(floored) Fuck me. (then, covering) Wonderful.
Joyce here will bring you to our legal department to sign the necessary paperwork. Nagopian stands and shakes Dale’s hand.  30.
Congratulations, Dale. We look forward to a long and profitable relationship with you and your Shower Buddy. (beat) That name? Is it a little gay?
Nope.
Fair enough.
Dale sits at a desk in another room as Joyce places a lar stack of documents in front of him.
All you have to do is sign on the last page for you and your partners.
Not so fast. If there’s one thing I know about business: you never sign anything without reading it carefully.
Take your time. She sits down as Dale begins to read the first page.
Two pages into the stack, Dale is BORED OUT OF HIS MIND a fighting to stay awake.
Okay, this all looks good. He flips to the last page and in an INSERT we see him sig first his own name, then forge the signatures of “Nick Hendricks” and “Kurt Buckman.”
Nick, dressed for work, joins Dale, still in his suit, an Kurt at an outdoor table.  31.
I have fifteen minutes, Dale. I never do lunch outside the office. What’s going on?
He wouldn’t tell me anything till you got here.
This isn’t something I could tell you over the phone.
Why are you wearing your church clothes? Kurt and Nick exchange a grave look.
Is it your unborn babies?
Oh, Dale. I’m so sorry. How’s Stacy doing?
She's fine! The babies are fine! Jesus.
Well, why did you scare us like that?
I didn’t scare anybody! You're scaring me.
So you dragged us out here to tell us your babies are fine?
No! This has nothing to do with my babies! You’re ruining this!
Ruining what?
This! He pulls a check from his jacket pocket and gingerly hold up for them to see. INSERT CHECK in the amount of ONE MILLION DOLLARS made ou Nick Hendricks, Kurt Buckman and Dale Arbus.  32.
What-- what are we looking at here, Dale?
Is that one of those Publishers Clearinghouse checks?
No. It’s a real check. From the venture capital place Denny Paul used. I pitched them the Shower Buddy and they loved it!
They loved the Shower Buddy?
They said it filled a niche.
Let me see that. He grabs the check and examines it.
Why would you do this without telling us?
